results.title: The Music of Mozart and Haydn
results.creator_credit: Dave Heather, Lexi Godfrey, Klein and EMI/Parlophone
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Castles and concerts”.
Set in the magnificent Haydnsaal of the Schloss Esterhazy in Eisenstadt, Austria and in the historic palaces of Vienna, the Polish Chamber Orchestra conducted by Jerzy Maksymiuk perform three beautiful pieces of chamber music by two of Austria’s greatest classical composers, Mozart and Haydn. Includes images of some of Austria’s picturesque landscapes, artworks and amazing palaces and gardens creating an ambient background to the music of the Orchestra. No commentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dave Heather, Lexi Godfrey, Klein and EMI/Parlophone

group_siblings.title: The Academy of St Martin in the Fields at Longleat
group_siblings.creator_credit: Dave Heather, Martin Wyn Griffith, Klein and EMI/Parlophone

results.title: The Academy of St Martin in the Fields at Longleat
results.creator_credit: Dave Heather, Martin Wyn Griffith, Klein and EMI/Parlophone
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Castles and concerts”.
Set in the idyllic historic Longleat House in Wiltshire, England, this program of popular classics is performed by The Academy of St Martin in the Fields conducted by world-renowned Neville Marriner (also artistic director). Neville Marriner introduces the program and provides a commentary on the history of Longleat House and the music of the great composers of the 17th and 18th centuries. Beautiful images of the Longleat Estate, both interior and exterior, accompany the music to provide an atmospheric re-creation of those earlier centuries.

results.title: Charley junior's schooldays
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Charley”.
Features the Education Act of 1944 and the improvements which may be expected in British education as a result of the Act. Charley Junior, a cartoon character, is eager to know about this future life. A nurse tells him about his school days; the different types of schools he will attend; the increase in education facilities and improvements in method; plans for the training of teachers and the construction of new schools. Voice: Max Adrian.

results.title: Charley's black magic
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Charley”.
A “Charley” cartoon showing the fundamental importance to the national economy of a plentiful supply of cheap coal. Britain’s source is at present coal but it is not cheap and to remedy the situation there is need for development and re-organisation of mines. The problem of finding enough money for this task will necessitate an increase in the cost of coal, but this situation will be improved as mines become more productive. Voices: Harold Berens, Jack Train.

results.title: Charley's march of time
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Charley”.
One of a cartoon series featuring the character “Charley”. In this film Charley questions the need for the National Insurance Acts of 1948, and by way of answer, he is taken back through the ages and shown how one man’s search for security has led him from one piece of social legislation to another. Animators: Wally Crook, Vera Linnecar, E. Williams and R. Privett.

results.title: Your very good health
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Charley”.
A cartoon illustrating various aspects of Britain’s National Health Service Scheme. Discusses in particular the effect of the scheme on the average British family.

results.title: Stencil colouring
results.brief_description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. Pathé Frères developed a stencil technqiue for colouring films that brought Casanova’s costumes alive and colour to his lovers’ cheeks.

constellations_primary.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_primary.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

results.description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. While Technicolor was decades away, the French production company Pathé Frères had developed a technique of stencil-colouring films around 1908. This process used a template for each colour – usually between three and six – and applied it frame by frame. Pathé continued innovating, developing mechanical devices to make the process faster and easier for the more than 400 women colourists working at the company. Thanks to Pathé’s stencil method, Casanova’s costumes shimmered in pink, orange and yellow, and rosy blushes graced his lovers’ cheeks.
description_for_label: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. While Technicolor was decades away, the French production company Pathé Frères had developed a technique of stencil-colouring films around 1908. This process used a template for each colour – usually between three and six – and applied it frame by frame. Pathé continued innovating, developing mechanical devices to make the process faster and easier for the more than 400 women colourists working at the company. Thanks to Pathé’s stencil method, Casanova’s costumes shimmered in pink, orange and yellow, and rosy blushes graced his lovers’ cheeks.

results.title: Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You
results.brief_description: Safeguard society by spying on your fellow citizens in this game based on the themes of George Orwell’s novel 1984 (1949).

constellations_primary.name: Orwell & Snowden
constellations_primary.description: Explores Orwell as a representation of the NSA, and the infamous Snowden leak.

results.description: Safeguard society by spying on your fellow citizens in this game based on the themes of George Orwell’s novel 1984 (1949). Transforming the dystopian thriller into a click-and-play game set in our contemporary online world, players are cast as government operatives who trawl social media profiles to uncover terrorists and political dissidents. Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You presents players with moral dilemmas, forcing them to think about their own ethics and beliefs when responding to the game’s reflection of our current society. It also asks them to analyse the effect of surveillance culture on society and the proliferation of false information and fake news.
description_for_label: Safeguard society by spying on your fellow citizens in this game based on the themes of George Orwell’s novel 1984 (1949). Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You presents players with moral dilemmas, forcing them to think about their own ethics and beliefs when responding to the game’s reflection of our current society. It also asks them to analyse the effect of surveillance culture on society and the proliferation of false information and fake news.
